sentences.sContent: When they first saw each other in royal clothing, the fine robes and shining crowns for their coronation, that was when they fell in love.
sentences.sContent_eng: When they first saw each other in royal clothing, the fine robes and shining crowns for their coronation, that was when they fell in love.
sentences.sCn: 当他们第一次看到对方穿着王室的衣服——为他们的加冕礼而穿戴的精美的袍子和华丽的王冠——时，那就是他们坠入爱河的时候。

sentences.sContent: What they regarded as the end of life was the very preparation for coronation; for Christ was silent that He might live again in tenfold power.
sentences.sContent_eng: What they regarded as the end of life was the very preparation for coronation; for Christ was silent that He might live again in tenfold power.
sentences.sCn: 她们所认为的生命末日，殊不知正是加冕大典的筹备过程；基督之所以静默安息，是为了在再醒时能增加十倍的力量。

sentences.sContent: But the world began to warm in 1650; when Charles II was crowned king of England in 1660, the coronation sparked the Enlightenment era in Europe.
sentences.sContent_eng: But the world began to warm in 1650; when Charles II was crowned king of England in 1660, the coronation sparked the Enlightenment era in Europe.
sentences.sCn: 但是从1650年开始，全球开始转暖，当查理二世于1660年在英国即位时，他的加冕礼成为启动欧洲启蒙时代的转机。

trans.tranOther: the ceremony at which someone is officially made king or queen
